citation.article-title: Haloanaerobium congolense sp. nov., an anaerobic, moderately halophilic, thiosulfate- and sulfur-reducing bacterium from an African oil field.

p.s: Description of Haloanaerobium congolense sp. nov.
Haloanaerobium congolense sp. nov.(con.go.len'se N.L. adj. congolense, from Congo, Central Africa).
Round colonies (diameter, 2 mm) are present after 1 week of incubation at 37°C.
Short rods that are 0.5-1 by 2-4 μm.
Cells occur singly or in pairs and are non-motile.
Gram-negative.
Chemoorganotrophic obligate anaerobe of the domain Bacteria.
The optimum temperature for growth is 42°C with no growth occurring below 20°C and over 45°C.
The optimum pH is 7.0 with growth occurring between pH 6.3 and 8.5.
Obligately halophilic.
The optimum NaCl concentration for growth is 10% and the NaCl concentration range for growth is 4-24%.
Doubling time under optimal conditions is about 2.5 h in the presence of glucose and thiosulfate.

Growth occurs on a range of carbohydrates including fructose, galactose, D-glucose, maltose, D-mannose, D-ribose, and sucrose but not on D-arabinose, lactose, rhamnose, D-xylose, dulcitol, acetate, butyrate, propionate, and lactate.
Yeast extract and/or bio-Trypcase are required for growth on carbohydrates and could not be replaced by amino acids (casein acid hydrolysate) and/or vitamins.
Thiosulfate and elemental sulfur are used as electron acceptors.
Thiosulfate improves carbohydrate utilization and cell biomass.
H2 inhibits growth, but this inhibition is reversed by the addition of thiosulfate.
The end-products from glucose fermentation are acetate, H2, and CO2.
The G+C content of the DNA is 34% (as determined by HPLC).
Isolated from an oil-injection water.
The type strain is SEBR 4224T (=DSM 11287).
